Fields.DialogueText: Hello there, Leberecht.
Leberecht? Why are you staring at me like that?
We're friends.
Uh... yes. Do you have a point?
Nein, nein. These are just unknown waters.
How do you mean?
Having someone actually admit to being my friend!

Fields.MenuText: How can someone admitting something so pathetic be so endearing?
It's really sweet that you think so much of our friendship.
I changed my mind. I don't want to be your friend.

Fields.DialogueText: You think I'm endearing?
Natürlich! I know very well how important it is not to take a good friendship for granted.
Don't toy with my feelings, Kapitän!
You certainly are the character, Leberecht.
One of the good characters, right? The type you can't help but root for in spite of their faults?
Yes, one of the good characters. And since you're one of the good characters, I think it's your responsibility to face those Morganas to our east head on.
Nur keinen Druck. No pressure, no pressure. We can do this.
@BATTLE
All right now, don't lose your mind.
Leberecht, can you come in here?
Jawohl, Kapitän. Do you need something?
I'd like your advice on something. I was working on some new battle strategies, and...
Gut, here's what I'm thinking. We construct a giant cage somewhere above the main deck of the ship.
When the lookout spots incoming Nixen, he'll notify the IO with a variety of hand gestures...
Leberecht, Leberecht! That's way too much.
Oh.
I just wanted to ask whether you had any input regarding ways we might improve weapon accuracy. Or any other, you know, easy to employ ideas.
Oh. You don't think my cage idea would be easy?

Fields.MenuText: Are you insane? That was one of the most elaborate plans I've ever heard.
Easy, no. I appreciate your creativity, to be sure.
Leberecht, if you could, by some miracle, figure out some way to pull your cage idea off, we'll do it.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh, I know, I know. I'll be the first to admit my brain doesn't work in conventional ways.
You're the master of the gentle letdown, aren't you, Kapitän?
Ja? Well, first we'll have to acquire a cage...
*ALARM*
No more time for talk. Leberecht, you'd better get to your station.
Ja, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
... And that is how you make a perfect Errötende Jungfrau. Or at least a pretty damn good one.
*applause* Ihre Präsentation war wunderbar! I've always been jealous of those who can make the dish with gelatine.
What can I say? My time in the Fleet has taught me to make the most of cheap substitutions.
I'd love to be able to do cheap substitutions like you do.
You're something else, you know that?
Ja.
Well, enough about gelatine. I believe I see a Morgana on the horizon.
You think we can eat and battle at the same time?
... I really wouldn't advise it.
@BATTLE
Kapitän? Do you think we could appease the Nixen by giving them Errötende Jungfrau? I mean, it always makes me happy.

Fields.MenuText: I really hope that that's some sort of joke...
It's a possibility, but you're the one who has to try doing it.
This is just your way of convincing me to make more Errötende Jungfrau, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Nein...?
Uh... I guess it isn't such a good idea...
I can neither confirm nor deny that fact.
How about we just defeat the Morganas? Appealing to the Morganas through any means seems like a recipe...
Heh.
... for disaster. No pun intended.
But made nonetheless! And fine, but just you watch. I will come up with some genius method of defeating the Nixen.
Sure you will.
Ja, werde ich! You'll be so jealous. I'm going to go off and think of it now, at this precise moment.
Such an imp, sometimes...
I left a couple books on my desk, and now they're gone. Come on now, guilty party. Own up to what you've done.
Oh, it was just me, Kapitän. I just took maybe two or... seven books on marksmanship. I'm just trying to learn.

Fields.MenuText: Give me those books back. You have no right to take things from my office.
Just leave a note the next time you remove something from my office, all right? I like to keep track of my things are.
Well, I like that initiative, Leberecht. Keep up the good work.

Fields.DialogueText: Es tut mir Leid, Kapitän! I had no idea you were so protective of your books.
Ja! I can do that! I probably should have thought to do that in the first place, now that I think about it.
Ja! Of course! And I apologize for not telling you I had the books earlier - I should have.
It's okay, Leberecht. Just return the books once you're done with them.
Natürlich! I'm a borrower, not a thief.
And have your studies been of use so far?
Maybe? It looks like there's a Nixe or two to our west. Perhaps I'll try implementing my studies right now.
@BATTLE
Kapitän?
Yes, Leberecht? What is it?
Someone stole one of my badges.
So?
I know it was you.
I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about. Now look, there's a Morgana that needs to be taken care of. We'll have to discuss this at a later time.
I'm not going to let you off the hook that easy!
@BATTLE
Now, admit it! You took my badge.
Heh. You're accusing an innocent person, Maass.
You can't even keep a straight face. Ich weiß, dass du es genommen hast.

Fields.MenuText: Never. How could you think that I, the very mature captain of this ship, would steal something?
As they say, an eye for an eye.
You're too smart for me, Leberecht. I thought it would take you longer to notice its absence, and even longer to identify me as the culprit.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Very mature, indeed. Stop this nonsense and give me my badge back.
Ha! Just as I expected - payback for taking your books, which I suppose I deserve. Now, lesson learned. May I have my badge back?
I'm not entirely without wits, thank you very much. Now, can I please have it back?
Fine, fine. Here you go.
I hope you know that you've just started a war. Be prepared, for Leberecht Maass will strike uno más... time.
Oh, I can't wait for this.
You think you're so sneaky, don't you, Leberecht?
Was meinst du damit, Kapitän? I have no idea what you're talking about.
Mmhmm.
Now, if you'll excuse me, there are duties I must attend to.
You're not going anywhere, Maass. Would you mind explaining where the compass in my office went?
You have a compass in your office?

Fields.MenuText: That amount of sass should be illegal. In fact, I'm going to arrest you, at which time I will confiscate any ill-gotten items.
I'll wrestle you to the ground right now if I need to.
My grandfather gave me that compass, you know. It's really important to me. I'm not sure whether I could continue my captainly duties without its reassuring presence.

Fields.DialogueText: Arrest me if you like, Kapitän, but I can tell you now - I have no stolen items on my person.
I might not be the strongest Belle, Kapitän, but know this. You can't take me.
Y-you're bluffing. I know it.
I'm bluffing, Leberecht. In fact, I already retrieved my compass.
Was? How?
*ALARM*
No time to explain. Let's get to it.
Drat.
@BATTLE
Hello, Kapitän. How are you doing today?
I'm... fine.
Sie scheinen müde zu sein. One might even say... sleep-deprived. You've been getting the necessary amount of shut-eye, haven't you?
You're one to talk. I know you were on lookout duty all night.
Ja, but I had lots of coffee. Also I'm a Belle. We're better equipped for that sort of thing.
How fortunate for you.
You still haven't told me why you're so tired.

Fields.MenuText: I was just mapping out some routes, that's all.
I just had some paperwork to finish up.
I was just engrossed in a really, really good book.

Fields.DialogueText: New routes? Where are we headed next? Spain, perhaps? I would really like to go to Spain.
That sounds so boring. I'm surprised you didn't fall asleep.
Maybe I could borrow it sometime, if it really was that good.
And are you sure that's what you were actually working on? Not, perhaps... a plan for revenge?
I would never be so juvenile.
Nein, natürlich nicht. I believe you implicitly.
I'm going to go back down to my quarters to...  get some rest. Maybe you should do the same.
That sounds like a good idea. Unfortunately, I think I sense some Nixen coming up off the port bow. Fight first, "sleep" second.
@BATTLE
Kapitän. I need to see you immediately.
Do you, now? I have no idea what this could possibly be about.
Such lies. You took everything except the heaviest of furniture out of my cabin.

Fields.MenuText: And I'm pretty damn proud of it.
You can't possibly pin that on me.
You're not at all upset, are you?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe if you had managed the heavier pieces as well.
You forget that I'm the Belle of the ship. I see and hear all, Kapitän.
Heh - natürlich nicht! It was an excellently executed prank, as far as I'm concerned.
Well, maybe next time you'll think twice before starting a prank war with me.
Ich kann es nicht garantieren. This one was pretty fun, after all. Still, for now - truce?
Truce.
*ALARM*
Figures. The Morganas can't help but show up when someone utters the word truce.
@BATTLE
Hey!
Kidding! I mean, mostly. I could have lifted them, after all.
There you are, Leberecht! How are you?
Ehrlich gesagt, I'm feeling pretty stressed, Kapitän. I've had a lot to do on the ship lately and I can't quite seem to find a moment to relax.

Fields.MenuText: I always find that standing on the bow of the ship calms me down. No one's usually up there and it's so quiet and peaceful.
Maybe someone on the ship can give you a massage if you ask nicely enough.
You could see how far your ration of alcohol gets you.

Fields.DialogueText: Now that you mention it, that does sound like a nice place to relax for a few minutes.
Very funny. As if anyone would get close enough to give me a massage. My bad luck has a reputation for rubbing off on others, remember?
I'm clumsy enough as is, Kapitän. I don't need to add alcohol to the mix.
It's all up to you, Leberecht. Figure out what might help, and do it. I want you taking care of yourself.
Danke, Kapitän. And I do appreciate the advice.
I am the wisest captain in all the land, after all.
Said with a straight face, even. Someone isn't lacking for self-confidence.
Well, I have you here to keep me humble, don't I?
You most certainly do.
*ALARM*
You think a good fight might help you let off a little steam?
Ja. Here's hoping.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! Come with me to the lower deck, please. I have something to show you.
Do you now?
I promise, it will be worth it.
What do you have to show me?
A few of the crew members and I raided the nearly-expired food in the pantry, and are planning on having an eating contest!
I thought that would be a great way to kick back and relax a bit, and thought you'd probably have a fun time watching.
Of course, you could always join in, if you liked...

Fields.MenuText: Leberecht, this is neither a good use of the crew's time nor their stomachs. I don't want them getting sick.
We can't let Command hear of this... but it does sound like a fun watch.
Oh, you're going down, Leberecht.

Fields.DialogueText: Give me a little credit, Kapitän. I thoroughly inspected every piece of food and can guarantee none of it has spoiled.
That's the spirit! You can hold the timer.
Is that a challenge?
Here, just take a seat, right here.
*ALARM*
The eating contest will have to wait a little longer, it sounds like.
Mist! Hopefully none of the food spoils while we're gone...
@BATTLE
You'd better believe it!
I have a proposition for you, Kapitän.
What might that be?
Since our prank war has ended... I have an idea for a new contest.
*ALARM*
I did have fun last time, so I suppose there's no harm in starting another. Let's discuss it after the battle.
Das hört sich nach einem Plan an, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Now that that's dealt with... what's your idea?
A storytelling competition. We need to try our best to scare, excite, amuse, and bring the crew to tears.
That doesn't sound so difficult.
Well, here's the kicker - you have to do so using the fewest words possible.

Fields.MenuText: Ha! I like the sound of that, and I'm a master of conciseness. Let's get to it.
I've never tried anything quite like that, but it does sound fun. I'll give it a go!
Fewest? I don't know... I have a tendency to ramble on... and on... and on... and on...

Fields.DialogueText: "Master of conciseness?" Give me a break...
Perfect. I can't wait to begin.
Well, perhaps this experience will teach you to be a little more efficient with your words.
All right, when do we start?
Soon. I'll come back to you once I have the rules prepared. Good luck. You're going to need it...
Kapitän!
Aah! Good grief, Leberecht. Why did you sneak up on me like that?
I'm just preparing you for the fear that's in store... huuuuuuuuuuuu...
*ALARM*
I'll be happy to listen to your story, once we deal with these Morganas. Get ready for battle.
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
All right, master of suspense. Let's hear it.
I don't like being alone at night, the silence is deafening. So I found myself a friend. The sound of her screaming and banging on the closet door helps me sleep at night.

Fields.MenuText: Good Lord, Leberecht, that was terrifying. Much darker than I was expecting.
It could've been scarier, but I applaud your efforts.
Terrible. I could do far better.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha ha! Mission accomplished, then.
Wirklich? Well, I guess I should know by now that there's always room for improvement in life.
Ach ja? I'd like to see you try.
I guess I really ought to get started on my story, already. I'll come up with something soon... be prepared.
Rest assured - I will be.
The Morganas are back, everyone! Get to your stations! This is not a drill!
@BATTLE
And, Leberecht. Since the battle is over and I have you here...
Ja, Kapitän?
I finally finished my story.
Das ist exzellent! I'm excited to hear it. What kind of story is it?

Fields.MenuText: Funny. On the way to the doctor, a mom sees her son with an apple in his hand. She tells him, "That won't keep the doctor away." The son replies, "It sent him running last time."
Scary. A girl goes to a carnival and notices a clown staring at her. She tells her friends about the clown, but her friends are confused - there are no clowns with this carnival.
Adventure. A boy runs, faster and faster, never stopping. Even as the end of the road approaches, he doesn't slow down. Then, skidding off the pavement, he flies.

Fields.DialogueText: You think that's funny?
I'll admit - I"m not a fan of clowns.
That can't be the end of the story! The adventure is only just starting!
So, who would you say won the story contest?
Honestly, I like my story better. But the crew has the final say.
Are you ready to take our stories out and see what they think?
Natürlich. And I think we should start planning our next contest as well. We should both come up with an idea.
That sounds like a great plan.
Dann sind wir uns einig. Let's get to it!
Well, yes...
Kapitän, have you come up with a new contest idea yet?
I have, believe it or not. Have you?
Ja! What's your idea?

Fields.MenuText: I think we should continue our storytelling contest.
Instead of an eating competition, a baking one?
What about a sports competition? We can play one-on-one. Make it a quick game.

Fields.DialogueText: Wirklich? Don't you think that's gotten a little boring?
Nein, das machen wir nicht. You know you'd win.
I don't know... I'm a pretty uncoordinated person.
If you don't like my idea, then it's your turn. What's your idea?
*ALARM*
Actually, hold that thought. We'll come back to this topic of conversation later.
@BATTLE
All right, Leberecht, let's hear it. What's your idea?
I was thinking that we could have a staring contest.
It sounds so simple... though simple isn't necessarily bad. Make sure your eyes are prepped and ready for this competition. I have a mean glare.
Just keep telling yourself that, Kapitän.
Okay, Kapitän. Ready to stare?
Ready as I'll ever be.
Ready...
Set...
*STARE*
*STARE*
It won't be long now...
It's cute that you think you're going to win.
Oh, I know I'm going to win.
Captain. There are Morganas approaching the main deck.
Aah! What? No!
That lookout sure knows how to project! How do we know who blinked first?

Fields.MenuText: It was definitely you.
I'll accept my defeat. I blinked first.
Can't we just call it a tie? There was an interruption.

Fields.DialogueText: No way! You blinked first.
I can't accept a forfeited victory. What if we tie?
Okay, that works!
Fine, we'll tie. There's no time for arguing, though. We have another contest to win.
@BATTLE
Leberecht? I wanted to thank you for all the contests you've roped me into. They've been fun, and have really helped me unwind.
Das ist wunderbar. I was hoping they would help you relax.
You really do have some genuinely essential talents, Leberecht. I'm just sorry they haven't gotten as much attention as they should.
Hey, I'll take what compliments I can get.

Fields.MenuText: You deserve more than you receive, in my opinion.
Don't let it go to your head.
You sure? I could take it back.

Fields.DialogueText: Awww, Kapitän. That's nice of you to say
I think I have a ways to go before I start developing any sort of ego.
You have an odd sense of humor sometimes, Kapitän...
Of course, now that we're out of contests, that means I need to go back to work.
Well, if you feel yourself getting stressed, I'm sure I could think of some new way for us to occupy our time.
*ALARM*
And until you do, the Morganas will keep us busy. Come on, it sounds like we're needed.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, what are you doing out here in this storm?
I'm waiting for the Morganas to arrive. What are you doing out here? I thought you'd be hiding below deck.
This storm is pretty mild, as far as storms go - we're in no danger of capsizing. At least for the moment.
And speaking of Nixen, there is a particular stench in the air...
And there they are... thinking they could use this rain as cover. Sound the alarm.
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
Has your life really been reduced to just standing around waiting for Nixen?
And filling out paperwork. That's the extent of it, at this point.
Ich verstehe.
... Does that make you happy?

Fields.MenuText: Content, at the very least. I like knowing I'm taking care of my people.
No. I could go for some excitement, right about now
What are you, my therapist?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course you're content, but that's not the same as happy.
I figured as much. Routine gets old, even for a Walküre who enjoys simple things, like me.
Not a therapist. Just a friend.
These constant battles, they wear, time spent out at sea, with no end in sight... it's all just a little much to handle, sometimes.
Zuerst... I think you should get some sleep. You humans get cranky without it, you know.
True enough. I appreciate your concern, Leberecht.
Natürlich, Kapitän!
Leberecht, is that you? I can't believe this rain still hasn't let up.
At least it isn't storming any more - this is a nice, peaceful drizzle. What do you think about the rain, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: It's gorgeous. In this light it's like liquid gemstones falling from the sky.
I don't like grey skies. It puts everyone in a more melancholic mood.
I have no opinion. It's just weather, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: How poetic of you, Kapitän.
You just need to look on the bright side of grey skies. No sunburns, for instance!
Scientifically speaking, yes. But I see more in it than just weather.
I've been trying to think of something I could do that would add a little more variety to my life, but haven't had any success thus far.
Why don't we write a book? It could be an extended version of our storytelling competition.
A book? You think? A collaboration between a human and Belle would certainly be of some interest...
Is that enthusiasm I hear in your voice?
Maybe...
*ALARM*
Das müssen wir wohl auf später verschieben. For now, some more Nixen need our attention.
What else is new?
@BATTLE
Leberecht, I just wanted to tell you that, since we started working on our book, I haven't had a bad night of sleep.
I'm happy to hear it. We should probably start on our outline, since we have a little time together.
Absolutely. Let's do this.
*ALARM*
... As soon as we've taken care of these Morganas.
@BATTLE
All right - let's get back to the book.
Jawohl! Now, I know we've discussed some potential characters, but we haven't nailed down a genre. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: Horror, without a doubt. I wouldn't read anything else.
Hmm... what do you think about a Western?
I'd really like to write a detective novel.

Fields.DialogueText: You know I love horror stories.
Like the Winnetou books? That could be interesting!
Oooooh, everyone loves a good mystery.
Or maybe... perhaps we could combine a few genres. That way, the story would have... oh, what's the term? I don't know. But it would appeal to lots of people.
Sounds perfect to me. When do we start writing?
Soon. I just have some work to take care of right now. Curse you for giving me jobs to do! Kidding, kidding.
Goodness, she's a character.
Calling to order to the first official meeting of the Writers' Guild!
... Leberecht, it's just the two of us.
Ja. I'm still calling it a guild. You can't stop me. I like guilds.
... I guess I can't. So what's the first order of business for today?
Since we have a genre, I think our next big decision should be choosing a title. Any ideas for our multi-genre book?

Fields.MenuText: The Splintered Thief.
The Voyage of Lords.
Twins of the Abyss.

Fields.DialogueText: Ooo, I like it! I want to read it already!
I'm already curious to find out where it is they're going.
How mysterious! Perfect.
That was easy enough. Now that that's done, what do we do next?
*ALARM*
That's what we should do next. Die Sitzung ist vertagt!
@BATTLE
Calling to order to the second meeting of the Writer's Guild!
Are you ever going to stop that?
No. Niemals! It makes me feel like I'm a part of something.
Of course it does. So, what's on the agenda for today?
I was thinking that we should consider the novel's opening words.
A good first line grabs the reader's attention and makes it impossible for them to put the book down. I have some ideas, what about you?

Fields.MenuText: You can never go wrong with the classic "It was a dark and stormy night."
Here's one. "When he woke up, he was surrounded."
I like the sound of, "On first glance, it would seem the meadow was completely empty."

Fields.DialogueText: Let's use a little more originality, shall we?.
Dropping the reader right into the middle of the action? I like that idea.
Not bad. Although, I'd like a little more excitement first thing. And drop the adverb.
Why don't I tell you my first line ideas next? First up is...
*ALARM*
Continue this conversation after this battle?
Natürlich!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, what are you doing out here in the rain again? Please don't tell me you're waiting for Nixen...
No, I'm done with that.
... Then what are those shadows I see out there on the horizon?
You have to be kidding me.
@BATTLE
So, what was it you were doing outside in the rain before the shooting started?
I was hoping to receive a little inspiration from the sky.
Ist das wirklich so? And? Did you learn anything?

Fields.MenuText: We're so small, in the grand scheme of things. Does all of this fighting even matter?
The world is so large, so infinite. Think about what that means for us - how many endless possibilities are available for us.
Not much. Although, I might've come up with a few ideas for the story.

Fields.DialogueText: We're still lives, in spite of our smallness. Of course this fighting matters.
I'm not always sure how much potential I have... but I do believe that most human beings can do anything they want.
That's good! We really need to continue our work. I don't want us falling behind!
Thanks for sitting out here with me for a bit, Leberecht.
Of course. Dafür sind Freunde doch da.
Do you think we're ever going to finish this book?
Of course, it's just... a long process.

Fields.MenuText: How long exactly? Do you think we might have bit off more than we could chew?
It'll all be worth it in the end. I don't care how long it takes.
You know, you could take the reins for a little while, if you wanted...

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not, Kapitän. We'll finish this book, just you wait and see.
I like that attitude. We can do this.
Not so fast, Kapitän. We started this project together, and we're going to finish it together.
I'll admit, I am excited to see the finished product.
So am I. We make a great team.
*ALARM*
Even when we're fighting those Morganas day after day?
Ja - especially then. Well, more or less. My aim could still use some improvement.
That's okay. Let's just get out there and do our best. I'm confident in our ability.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I need to talk to you immediately. It's about the book.
What is it? Did all our work go up in flames? Did you drop it over the edge of the boat? Leberecht, I know you can be very clumsy sometimes...
Every page is safely put away. I just have a question for you.
Can it wait? I see some Morganas coming in fast. Prepare for battle.
@BATTLE
Now back to my question. I think our story should have a Moral. I want people to be able to learn something from it. What do you think it should be?
A moral? Well...

Fields.MenuText: I think it should show that we never know how life is going to work out. And that that's not necessarily a bad thing.
I think it should teach people to work hard. We can't rely on others to do work for us. If we truly want to live life, we have to put in the effort.
I want the book to have the message that you should believe in yourself. We're capable of far more than we often believe

Fields.DialogueText: How true! I think that's an excellent Moral, Kapitän.
I like that. There are too many lazy people who take advantage of others. It's important to have a strong work ethic.
I'm not sure that's true for all people... or Walküre... but I think it's a great message nonetheless.
Danke, Kapitän! I'll make sure to write it down right now. Thanks!
Any time, Leberecht.
Leberecht? There's been something bothering me.
What's that, Kapitän? ... Hold that thought. I'm sensing some incoming Nixen who are itching for a fight.
@BATTLE
Pfennig for your thoughts?
What if this book goes nowhere? I mean, I know it's not going to be published or anything, but I also don't want it sitting in a corner getting dusty.
We can spread it around the ship, hand it off from person to person. The crew is always looking for new means of entertainment.

Fields.MenuText: Don't you think it's rather inefficient to just pass a single copy between so many people?
You think the crew will really like it?
Do you think we should have written something... I don't know. More serious?

Fields.DialogueText: We can always make more copies. It will take some time, but we have plenty of that on this ship.
Of course! I mean, I like it, so why wouldn't they?
I think this was the perfect story to start with. There will always be time for writing other sorts of books later.
You make a good point.
Gelegentlich, ja. Now... are you ready to get back to work, Kapitän?
Of course, Leberecht.
